questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his parent after injuring his arm. The patient broke up with his partner earlier today; several hours later, his parent found him in his room attempting to use a knife to cut his wrist. He has been hospitalized four times for similar suicide attempts in the past three years following breakups with romantic partners. The patient reports that he was not trying to kill himself and that “I just feel like I don’t know how to deal with anger and stress.” His parent mentions that, since middle school, the patient has had periods of sadness lasting 1-2 days in which he goes into a “bottomless black hole,” where it is “near impossible” to make him feel better. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple rows of well-healed scars bilaterally on the wrists. Which of the following defense mechanisms does this patient most likely demonstrate considering his most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with unstable interpersonal relationships, poor self-image, mood lability, anger, impulsivity, and recurrent suicide attempts most likely has borderline personality disorder.  

Splitting is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual classifies people as entirely good or entirely bad and can rapidly shift between these two extreme opinions (e.g. a student who dislikes all teachers but believes all student counselors are good people based on their choice of profession alone). Splitting is a characteristic defense mechanism used by patients with borderline personality disorder.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   

Option Analysis

❌ Sublimation:
Incorrect: Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism in which an unacceptable impulse or behavior is shifted towards goal-directed, socially acceptable activities (e.g. a person redirects their aggressive behavior into contact sports). It is not a characteristic defense mechanism used by patients with borderline personality disorder.
❌ Altruism:
Incorrect: Altruism as a defense mechanism refers to alleviating negative feelings via unsolicited generosity, which provides gratification (e.g. giving the homeless person your lunch instead of eating it yourself).
❌ Suppression:
Incorrect: Intentionally withholding an idea or feeling from conscious awareness is referred to as suppression. It can be a mature defense mechanism; an example is a surgeon suppressing feelings of fear associated with the sight of blood during surgery to provide necessary patient care.
✅ Splitting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Displacement:
Incorrect: Displacement is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual redirects emotions in a destructive or socially unacceptable way to a less threatening object or person (e.g. a teenager who is verbally abused by their teacher yells at their younger sibling at home). It is not a characteristic defense mechanism used by patients with borderline personality disorder.

questions.text: A 23-year-old person is hospitalized because of suicidal ideation. They describe a deep sense of emptiness and sadness for the past two weeks, since the end of their relationship. They were brought to the emergency department one month ago by their partner after ingesting multiple acetaminophen tablets, and they have been admitted to the hospital several times in the past few months after attempted self-harm. They claim that their ex-partner is “extremely selfish” and “does not care for me.” They feel betrayed by their partner and want their partner to pay attention to them. The patient’s parent, who is accompanying them, states that the patient is prone to outbursts of physical aggression, mood swings, and feelings of insecurity about themself. The mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of “exuberance and affection” to states of “depression.” On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and tearful. The rest of the examination is otherwise unremarkable. The physician decides to initiate a therapy that focuses on stress tolerance, coping skills development, emotional regulation, self-management, and suppression of secondary gain. Which of the following forms of therapy was most likely initiated?
questions.solution:
This patient with unstable interpersonal relationships, poor self-image, mood lability, anger, as well as impulsivity and recurrent suicide attempts most likely has borderline personality disorder (BPD).  

For a patient with BPD, clinical trials have shown first-line treatment of psychotherapy to be efficacious. Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is the treatment of choice. In the initial stages of treatment, a supportive approach is used to establish a therapeutic alliance. Over time, the therapist focuses on identifying and changing ineffective behaviors. The emphasis is on stress tolerance, coping skills development, emotional regulation, self-management, and suppression of secondary gain from acting-out behavior. Another core component of DBT is the availability of the therapist by phone or other means between sessions to provide coaching and to facilitate the application of skills learned during therapy sessions to the natural environment.  

Besides BPD, dialectical behavioral therapy is effective in eating disorders, trauma-related disorders, and depressive disorder associated with suicidal thoughts.  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.    

Option Analysis

❌ Cognitive behavioral therapy:
Incorrect: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) combines cognitive therapy and behavior therapy; it aims to change distorted, harmful, irrational, or ineffective beliefs, attitudes, and behavior patterns that lead to impairment of function in an individual. Treatment is usually limited (involves 5-20 sessions), is structured, and involves homework. It is indicated in OCD, PTSD, depression, and generalized anxiety disorder. There have been several studies examining the efficacy of CBT in treating patients with borderline personality disorder, but results have been mixed thus far.
❌ Psychodynamic therapy :
Incorrect: Psychodynamic therapy emphasizes how certain life events and relationships, both past and present, affect your current feelings, relationships, and choices. This vignette instead describes dialectical behavioral therapy, the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder.  
❌ Family therapy:
Incorrect: Family therapy identifies family dysfunctions and individual problems that affect the entire family. It aims to reduce conflict and helps accommodate every member within a family unit. Typical indications include schizophrenia and eating disorders. This vignette instead describes dialectical behavioral therapy, the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder.
✅ Dialectical behavioral therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Experiential therapy :
Incorrect: Experiential therapy, also known as humanistic therapy, focuses on a person’s individual nature with a holistic approach that emphasizes the whole person, their positive behaviors, ability to grow, and find self-actualization through self-exploration. This vignette instead describes dialectical behavioral therapy, the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office for a routine physical examination. After waiting an hour, he begins to berate the receptionist and demands to be seen by a doctor. He says that other patients in the waiting room had tried to engage him in a conversation about their own problems. He says, “My health is far more important than their health! After all, I am the owner of a multinational bank!” During the visit, the patient expresses irritation in having to take the time out of his busy schedule and is under a lot of stress lately. The patient talks about feeling depressed because of multiple failed relationships, even though he is a “great romantic.” He recently broke up with his partner because they canceled a plan with him in order to visit their parents after their grandmother’s death. Past medical and family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best explanation for this patient’s behavior?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, sense of entitlement, and lack of empathy is consistent with narcissistic personality disorder, a cluster B personality disorder.  

Narcissistic personality disorder is characterized by a long-standing pattern of grandiosity with a need for praise and admiration that stands out in contrast to a lack of sensitivity to the feelings of others. These persons may display an exaggerated sense of self-importance and social status and require excessive admiration. They may be driven toward attaining an idealized position in terms of social, personal, romantic, or professional accomplishment. These patients often have unstable relationships because of their inability to recognize or identify the feelings of others. In a medical setting, these patients may feel entitled to special treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of deceitfulness, aggression, recurrent criminal activity, impulsivity, disregard for one's safety and/or the safety of others, lack of remorse and/or emotional indifference to the plight of others, and a failure to fulfill obligations at work and/or home. They also display evidence of childhood conduct disorder. In contrast, this patient is less aggressive and deceitful than are persons with antisocial personality disorder.
✅ Narcissistic personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: This patient does not exhibit the mood lability, impulsivity, splitting, and recurrent suicidal behavior seen in borderline personality disorder (BPD). Moreover, BPD would not explain this patient’s sense of entitlement, grandiosity, and lack of empathy.
❌ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder:
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD) is characterized by rigid perfectionism and a strong need to meet internal high standards. The patient in the vignette seeks to surpass the standards of those around him, and OCPD would not explain this patient’s sense of entitlement, grandiosity, and lack of empathy.
❌ Histrionic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Histrionic personality disorder is distinguished by a pervasive pattern of attention-seeking behavior. Patients with this disorder are often uncomfortable in situations in which they are not the center of attention. They typically use physical appearance, dramatic speech, and exaggerated emotionality to draw attention to themselves. Histrionic personality disorder would not explain this patient’s sense of entitlement, grandiosity, and lack of empathy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine check-up at the prompting of her parent. The patient’s parent reports that the patient has endured emotional abuse by her partner. The patient refuses to end the relationship with her partner and feels uneasy when the partner is not around. She adds, “I'm worried that if I leave the relationship, my life will only get worse.” She has not been employed since she started dating and living with her partner, and she is convinced that nobody would hire her. A review of her medical record indicates that she has endured several episodes of verbal abuse from prior relationships, which she suggested “were all her fault.” She has had four prior serious relationships and reports that she has not been single for more than a few weeks in the last 10 years. The patient’s parent states that they manage most of her finances and that the patient is “unable to handle it on her own.” She does not have any friends outside of her romantic relationship. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s behavior?
questions.solution:
This patient’s excessive dependence on her partner (despite emotional abuse), indecisiveness, and the fear of managing on her own is consistent with dependent personality disorder (DPD), a cluster C personality disorder.  

DPD is characterized by a pervasive psychological dependence on other people. People with DPD experience intense fear of separation and abandonment and feel great discomfort when they are alone. This leads to submissive and clinging behavior in their interpersonal relationships. These patients have difficulty making independent decisions without a great deal of advice and reassurance, and they are often afraid of disagreeing with others. They lack self-confidence and believe that they cannot adequately care for themselves. These individuals are particularly vulnerable to becoming trapped in abusive relationships.  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute stress disorder:
Incorrect: Acute stress disorder is an intense, unpleasant, and dysfunctional reaction beginning shortly after an overwhelming traumatic event and lasting less than a month. It is characterized by intrusive re-experiencing of the trauma and avoidance of reminders of the incident. 
❌ Separation anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with separation anxiety disorder may demonstrate excessive fear and anxiety about being alone, similar to this woman's uneasiness when her partner is not present. However, these patients demonstrate a preoccupation with losing an attachment figure or reluctance to leave home, which often manifests as excessive worrying, nightmares, and/or physical complaints not seen in this patient. In addition, separation anxiety disorder is seen more commonly in children.
✅ Dependent personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Avoidant personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with avoidant personality disorder strongly fear interpersonal rejection and tend to avoid relationships due to fear of ridicule or rejection. In contrast, this patient’s excessive dependence on her partner despite the emotional abuse is suggestive of dependent personality disorder.  
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although fear of abandonment is also seen in borderline personality disorder (BPD), these individuals tend to react with rage and have demanding and dramatic behavior; this behavior is unlike patients with dependent personality disorder, who are typically more submissive. Moreover, this patient lacks the mood lability and self-destructive behavior seen in BPD.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department after sustaining injuries in a street fight. The patient was crossing the street with his partner when he became suspicious of a group of people for staring at them, and he started a fight. The patient's partner reports that he had been involved in similar fights a couple of times since they started dating. They have heard stories from the patient’s mother of his violent behavior, including fist fights throughout middle school and high school that resulted in multiple suspensions and even an expulsion. He has changed multiple jobs over the past few years as those were “too easy for him.” The patient’s family history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco but drinks alcohol occasionally and has used cocaine on several occasions. Urine toxicology in the emergency department is negative. This patient’s behavior is most consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has an unstable employment history, reckless disregard for safety of self or others, and a probable history of conduct disorder (i.e. violent behavior in school); he most likely has antisocial personality disorder (ASPD), which belongs to the cluster B personality disorders.   

Individuals with ASPD disregard moral values and societal norms, have little empathy, and demonstrate poor impulse control. This combination makes them willing to hurt others if it helps them, making them prone to aggressive and unlawful behavior, at times being labeled as sociopaths or psychopaths. They often tend to be overrepresented in prison populations and have higher rates of substance use. These individuals typically fail to show remorse or guilt and rarely accept responsibility for any of the harm that they cause others. ASPD is more common in males than females.  

The diagnostic criteria for ASPD is shown in the table below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Conduct disorder:
Incorrect: Conduct disorder is diagnosed in children and adolescents with a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior violating basic rights of others or major societal norms or rules. If the symptoms persist ≥18 years of age, it is reclassified as antisocial personality disorder.
❌ Intermittent explosive disorder:
Incorrect: Although aggression can occur in both antisocial personality disorder and intermittent explosive disorder (IED), the aggression seen in IED is not premeditated or intended to defy rules or gain advantage over others. Aggression seen in IED is typically a disproportionate reaction to any provocation, real or perceived (e.g., impulsive shouting, screaming or excessive reprimanding triggered by relatively inconsequential events).  
✅ Antisocial personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Substance use disorder:
Incorrect: Although drug use can contribute to antisocial behavior, this patient’s history of conduct disorder in adolescence as well as negative urine toxicology makes antisocial personality disorder the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Oppositional defiant disorder:
Incorrect: Oppositional defiant disorder is defined as anger, irritable mood, and defiant behavior toward authority figures that significantly impairs social and/or academic functioning. It does not include physical aggression or intention to defy rules, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the office by his parent because of concerns about his behavior over the past two years. The patient does not have friends and spends much of his time involved in computer programming or playing games on his computer. He becomes distant when asked questions about his personal life and how he likes spending his time. Throughout the interview, the boy makes poor eye contact and gives brief answers to questions. He states that he likes to keep to himself and is not interested in being around people. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. Affect is flat. He appears to dislike being interviewed by both the medical student and the physician. This patient’s behavior is most consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and a flattened affect, all of which are classic features of schizoid personality disorder. Schizoid personality disorder is a part of the cluster A personality disorders, which are characterized by odd and eccentric thinking/behavior.  

Schizoid personality disorder describes people who are aloof and avoid social interaction because they are not interested in getting to know others. Importantly, this avoidance is not because social interaction causes them anxiety or because they think there are possible threats; rather, it is a pure lack of interest. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder may also find physical contact in all forms to be less pleasurable, from sexual activity to holding hands, leading these individuals to be far less motivated to seek out physical relationships with others. In addition, they might also have a flat affect and emotional blunting, with apparent indifference to praise or criticism.  



Option Analysis

✅ Schizoid personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Avoidant personality disorder:
Incorrect: In contrast to schizoid personality disorder, individuals with avoidant personality disorder desire relationships with others but tend to avoid them due to feelings of inadequacy and hypersensitivity to rejection and criticism. This patient expresses a desire to keep to himself and states that he is not interested in being around people, which is instead indicative of schizoid personality disorder.
❌ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder do tend to have a constricted affect and lack of close friends due to discomfort in social interactions and an impaired capacity for close relationships. However, in contrast to this patient, individuals with schizotypal personality disorder have eccentric behavior (e.g. peculiar speech) and distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), which are not seen in this case.
❌ Autism spectrum disorder:
Incorrect: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and communication but also includes repetitive and stereotyped behavior, interests, and activities. Symptoms of this disorder typically manifest in early childhood, not adolescence. Moreover, this patient’s lack of stereotyped behavior makes ASD an unlikely diagnosis.
❌ Social phobia:
Incorrect: In contrast to schizoid personality disorder, individuals with social phobia have marked and enduring anxiety for one or more social situations in which the person is exposed to or observed by unknown people. Instead of expressing fear or anxiety, this patient expresses a desire to keep to himself and states that he is not interested in being around people, which is more indicative of schizoid personality disorder.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to her physician’s office for an annual examination and is accompanied by her parent. The patient is doing well in college and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a sales associate at a store, but she declined it because she prefers to work alone and would rather continue doing her job that requires less interaction with customers, which she feels she wouldn’t be very good at. The patient’s parent describes the patient as extremely shy and the “silent one” since childhood. The patient has few friends and does not date, stating, “I mean, I’d love to be in a relationship, but no one would ever want to be with someone ugly and stupid like me.” The patient describes her mood as “unhappy” but does not report changes in mood, appetite, or feelings of suicidal ideation. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. This patient’s presentation is consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s avoidance of social interactions, feelings of inadequacy, and poor ability to form relationships despite desiring them is consistent with avoidant personality disorder, a cluster C personality disorder.  

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation. If they do engage in social situations or relationships, they are constantly preoccupied with being rejected, criticized, and not being liked by others. As a result, these patients have low self-esteem, feel socially inept, have feelings of inferiority, and are shy and inhibited. Avoidant personality disorder usually starts at a young age; however, it is not generally diagnosed until the patient is older than 18 years old (as is the case with most personality disorder diagnoses). The trait appears to be stable throughout adulthood. The social anxiety patients experience is thought to be due to dysfunction in the amygdala and its connections.    


A person with avoidant personality disorder desires relationships with others, unlike schizoid personality disorder in which a person prefers to be alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: While patients with schizoid personality disorder do tend to avoid social situations and relationships, they expressly desire this social isolation. In contrast, patients with avoidant personality disorder strongly desire relationships but avoid them because of anxiety and fears of rejection and humiliation.
✅ Avoidant personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder have eccentric behavior (e.g. peculiar speech) and distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Dependent personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with dependent personality disorder also strongly fear interpersonal rejection, but they do not avoid relationships; instead, they actively seek them.
❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to be cold and detached, and they are prone to deceitful, manipulative, and impulsive behavior. They also disregard laws and ethical norms if this provides them personal profit or pleasure. Furthermore, this diagnosis is only made if the individual is ≥ 18 years of age and there is evidence of conduct disorder prior to 15 years of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office accompanied by his partner for a routine physical examination. The patient has not had a physical checkup in the last 10 years and visited the office today after prolonged convincing by his partner. When asked, the patient says, “Doctors always try their best to make a diagnosis that requires multiple tests to make more money.” The patient has no active complaints at this visit. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s partner reports that the patient has always been suspicious of them having an extra-marital affair in the office and has asked them to quit their job. The patient divorced his first partner because of the suspicion that they were still secretly dating their ex-partner from college. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. During the physical examination, the patient repeatedly asks why the physician is performing each exam maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with long-standing suspiciousness in relationships and mistrust of others (including medical professionals) is characteristic of paranoid personality disorder (PPD).  

PPD is a part of the cluster A personality disorders, which are characterized by odd and eccentric thinking or behavior. PPD describes someone who is accusatory or generally distrustful and suspicious of other people without reason; patients with PDD often assume that others will disappoint them, manipulate them, or talk about them behind their back. Patients may also think excessively about making sure that they have the loyalty of their friends and family.  

This paranoia is usually so strong that it affects the way individuals with PDD act; patients typically react severely if they feel that they have been lied to or slighted in any way, which can result in their holding grudges for long periods of time. Patients also tend to have superficial relationships because it becomes difficult to develop close bonds when they accuse the people in their lives of things like cheating without having substantive proof. In physician-patient relationships, these individuals can manifest as difficulty establishing rapport or a therapeutic alliance.  



Option Analysis

❌ Intermittent explosive disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with intermittent explosive disorder are periodically unable to restrain impulses that result in verbal or physical aggression. This patient, who is accusatory and suspicious of other people, most likely has paranoid personality disorder.
❌ Conduct disorder:
Incorrect: Conduct disorder refers to repetitive, pervasive behavior violating societal norms or the basic rights of others (e.g., aggression toward people and animals, destruction of property, theft) before the age of 18 years. This patient, who is accusatory and suspicious of other people, most likely has paranoid personality disorder.
❌ Avoidant personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with avoidant personality disorder can demonstrate a reluctance to initiate projects due to low self-confidence. Additionally, they tend to avoid relationships due to fear of ridicule or rejection; in contrast, this patient ended his previous relationship on the basis of suspicion. In addition, avoidant personality disorder is not characterized by pervasive distrust, suspiciousness, hypervigilance, and a profoundly cynical view of the world.
❌ Delusional disorder, persecutory type:
Incorrect: Patients with delusional disorder, persecutory type, believe that they are being conspired against, and the belief is specific and unshakable. In cases of PPD, like this patient, the delusions are non-specific with a generalized suspicion.
✅ Paranoid personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle accident. The patient is conscious and has minor lacerations over the right forearm. On further questioning, the patient says, “I was passing by a big sale on car tires, and then later on, I was involved in an accident caused by tire failure. That store was selling new tires, and therefore, other tires had to fail.” The patient believes he has a “sixth sense” which enables him to predict bad events before they happen. He lives alone at home and says, “I prefer it this way.” Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a middle-aged man with multiple lacerations on the right forearm. On mental status examination, it is noted that the patient is wearing undergarments on the outside and multiple layers of mismatched clothing underneath. The patient has a flat affect and avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s eccentric appearance, odd/magical beliefs (e.g. can predict bad events), and interpersonal deficits are most consistent with schizotypal personality disorder, a cluster A personality disorder. 

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder behave in an odd and eccentric manner and experience cognitive or perceptual distortions. They may seem overly superstitious or might engage in excessive magical thinking (may think that two completely random events are causally linked, as seen in this patient). Related to this would be ideas of reference, which is a belief that everything, including innocuous events or coincidences that happen in the world, directly relate to one’s own destiny. Patients with schizotypal personality disorder often believe that they are particularly in-tune with the events around them, leading to overconfidence and a self-centered way of speaking that is socially inappropriate. Patients also often dress in an odd and peculiar fashion. They are socially isolated and usually have few or no close friends, which stems from their odd behavior as well as from their persistent social anxiety due to suspiciousness or paranoia toward others.  

Family studies show an increased incidence of schizophrenia in relatives of patients with schizotypal personality disorder and vice versa. Therefore, schizotypal personality disorder is included as a schizophrenia spectrum disorder.  

Option Analysis

❌ Paranoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although individuals with paranoid personality disorder are suspicious and have paranoia, they do not typically present with the odd and peculiar mannerisms and behaviors seen in schizotypal personality disorder; they also lack cognitive or perceptual distortions.
❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although individuals with schizoid personality disorder prefer to be alone (like this patient), they do not typically present with the odd and peculiar mannerisms and behaviors seen in schizotypal personality disorder; they also lack cognitive or perceptual distortions.
✅ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Schizophrenia is characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech and behavior, plus characteristic negative symptoms. Although this patient has a flat affect, his odd beliefs are not held with delusional intensity, and he lacks other psychotic symptoms required to make a diagnosis.
❌ Histrionic personality disorder:
Incorrect: This patient lacks the personality features of histrionic personality disorder, which is characterized by attention-seeking behaviors, dramatic speech and emotional expressions, shallow and labile emotions, and sexually provocative actions/behaviors. In contrast, this patient prefers to stay alone and has odd beliefs and distorted perceptions, more characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the office due to a suspicion of being poisoned. The patient states that when he left for work this morning, he was certain that he had closed the door of the refrigerator. However, upon returning home, he saw that the refrigerator was slightly open. The patient is suspicious that his neighbors have been tampering with his food lately and that they may have poisoned him. He states that he suspects that his neighbors have been trying to break into his house and steal things ever since he moved here. He has tried multiple times to get them evicted from the building and expresses concern that “Now they’re trying to get their revenge.” When the physician states that there are no signs or symptoms of poisoning, the patient becomes suspicious of the physician, asking if they are secretly working with his neighbors. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient demonstrates a chronic and pervasive pattern of distrust and suspiciousness; these symptoms are characteristic of paranoid personality disorder (PPD).  

PPD is a cluster A personality disorder that is characterized by generalized distrust and suspiciousness. Individuals with PPD tend to view others’ actions as hostile and will often bear grudges. Patients with PPD often lead guarded lives, which can be associated with other disorders such as schizoid personality disorder. There appears to be an epidemiological link between the cluster A personality disorders (paranoid, schizoid, and schizotypal) and schizophrenia. However, patients with cluster A disorders do not have persistent psychotic symptoms – though during periods of stress, patients with PPD may develop brief psychotic episodes.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder typically present with voluntary social withdrawal and limited emotional expression. This patient’s pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others is consistent with a different diagnosis. 
✅ Paranoid personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Incorrect: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric appearances, interpersonal awkwardness, as well as odd/magical thinking. This patient’s pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others is consistent with a different diagnosis. 
❌ Borderline personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with borderline personality disorder typically have a history of instability with interpersonal relationships, self-image, and impulse control. This patient’s pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others is consistent with a different diagnosis. 
❌ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder:
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is characterized by a consistent pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control. This patient’s distrust and suspiciousness of others is consistent with a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her sister due to persistent suicidal ideation. The patient describes a deep sense of emptiness and sadness for the past two weeks, since the end of her relationship with her partner after six weeks of dating. She was brought to the emergency department one month ago by her partner after ingesting multiple acetaminophen tablets when they first attempted to break up with her. She has been admitted to the hospital several times in the past few months after attempted self-harm. She says that her partner is “extremely selfish” and “does not care for her.” The patient’s sister states that the patient is prone to outbursts of physical aggression and mood swings. The mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of “exuberance and affection” to states of “depression.” On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and tearful. The rest of the examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with unstable interpersonal relationships, poor self-image, mood lability, anger, as well as impulsivity and recurrent suicide attempts, most likely has borderline personality disorder (BPD), which belongs to the cluster B personality disorders.  

Patients with BPD exhibit instability in their self-image, affect, and relationships with others. Their relationships often involve extreme idealization and devaluation (i.e. splitting). Patients can be impulsive and may engage in self-destructive behaviors, such as substance misuse, self-mutilation, and suicide attempts. These behaviors reflect a deep sense of emptiness and an intense fear of abandonment by others. They may also have transient psychotic symptoms (e.g., paranoia and delusions) under severe stress. Borderline personality disorder usually manifests by early adulthood and is three times more common in females than males.  

The diagnostic criteria for BPD is described in the table below.  

 PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Antisocial personality disorder:
Incorrect: Individuals with antisocial personality disorder disregard moral values and societal norms, have little empathy, and demonstrate poor impulse control. This combination makes them willing to hurt others if it helps them, making them prone to aggressive and unlawful behavior. Recurrent suicide attempts and mood lability are usually not seen.
✅ Borderline personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: This patient has insufficient quantity and duration of symptoms to be diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Diagnosis requires recurrent episodes lasting ≥ 2 weeks characterized by ≥ 5 of 9 diagnostic symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt, sleep disturbances, suicidal ideation, psychomotor slowing, decreased appetite/weight changes, decreased concentration, and loss of energy.
❌ Intermittent explosive disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with intermittent explosive disorder can become enraged in response to interpersonal conflicts; these patients, however, lack the characteristic borderline personality features seen in this patient (i.e., suicidal behavior, mood lability, fear of abandonment).
❌ Phencyclidine intoxication:
Incorrect: Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can present with violent behavior, and the patients usually have nystagmus. This patient’s normal physical exam and pattern of suicidal behavior and fear of abandonment are not explained by PCP intoxication.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her partner because of a self-inflicted laceration of the left wrist. The patient states that she knew her partner was having sexual thoughts about the woman from the grocery store, prompting her decision to cut her own wrist in an attempt to end her life. Past medical history is significant for a similar emergency department visit a few months ago when she was struggling with online dating. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit substances. During the interview, she is teary-eyed and apologizes for “making a scene.” She expresses gratitude to the physician for her care, and she expresses regret for her actions. The patient states that she always struggles with her romantic relationships though she deeply desires them. After a complete physical examination and appropriate wound care for the laceration, the physician tells the patient that she will have to stay in the psychiatric emergency department for the night, which makes her furious, resulting in verbal assault of the physician and the nurses by the patient. Which of the following answer choices best characterizes the pattern of behavior exhibited by this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a history of multiple suicide attempts and emotional lability, suggesting a diagnosis of borderline personliaty disorder.

When the thought patterns or behaviors which make up a person’s personality are harmful to the point where they interfere with their day-to-day functioning in their personal life, at work, or in social settings, it is referred to as a personality disorder. To diagnose a personality disorder, three general criteria must be met (in addition to exhibiting features specific to the individual personality disorder):  
  1.  The presence of a constant pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates substantially from the cultural norm, manifested in two or more of the following four areas: cognition; affectivity, intensity, and appropriateness of emotional responses; interpersonal functioning; and impulse control. 
  2.  The pattern is inflexible and is present in most personal and social situations, including relationships, work, and school. 
  3. The pattern is stable, of long duration, and its onset is in adolescence or early adulthood.
The patterns should not be attributable to a substance like alcohol or another medical condition. The DSM-5 lists ten personality disorders that are split into clusters A, B, and C, as outlined in the table below.  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Anxiety disorders are characterized by inappropriate experiences of fear and their physical manifestations incongruent with the magnitude of the stressors, not attributable to another psychiatric disorder, medical condition (e.g. hyperthyroidism), or substance misuse. This patient’s inflexible, maladaptive, and rigidly pervasive pattern of behavior causing subjective distress and/or impaired functioning is instead suggestive of borderline personality disorder.
❌ Personality trait:
Incorrect: Personality traits may be described as an enduring pattern of perceiving, relating to, or thinking about the environment, oneself, or others that is usually stable and predictable and does not affect a person’s functioning in daily life. This patient’s behavior is interfering with her day-to-day functioning.
✅ Personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Conduct disorder:
Incorrect: Conduct disorder is diagnosed in children and adolescents with a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior violating basic rights of others or major societal norms or rules. If the symptoms persist ≥18, it is reclassified as antisocial personality disorder. However, this patient’s behavior is instead self-destructive, lending toward a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder.
❌ Psychosis:
Incorrect: Psychosis is characterized by distorted perception of reality characterized by delusions, hallucinations, and/or disorganized thought/speech. While this patient’s suicide attempt was prompted by a suspicion about her partner (whether true or untrue), the overall presentation, history and response to the plan for a psychiatric hold are more characteristic of borderline personality disorder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping. She recently moved into the area after quitting her old job as a newscaster on a local television station, stating “there was no room for me there.” She became extremely upset after she saw her photograph still featured on the television’s website last week. She recalls another job that she had to quit because her boss thought she was difficult to work with. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Physical examination shows a young woman who is teary-eyed when discussing her situation and moves closer to the physician throughout the interview. She repeatedly attempts to touch the physician during the physical exam, making inappropriate comments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's exceptionally attention-seeking and sexually provocative behavior, in combination with dramatic emotional display, suggests a diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder, which belongs to the cluster B personality disorders.  

The key feature of this personality disorder is attention-seeking behavior and excessive emotionality, which sometimes leads patients to manipulate a situation to draw more attention to themselves. For example, they might act inappropriately flirtatious or tell overly dramatized stories to remain the center of attention. These behaviors result in superficial relationships with many acquaintances, but few, if any, deep connections with good friends or romantic partners since others tend to view them as shallow, flighty, and egocentric. To establish a diagnosis, it is required that the patient demonstrates a persistent pattern of problematic behavior since early adulthood and across multiple contexts.  



Option Analysis

❌ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Incorrect: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, social anxiety (due to paranoid ideations), and cognitive or perceptual distortions. This patient’s attention-seeking behavior, inappropriate provocation, and dramatic displays of emotions in public settings are instead suggestive of histrionic personality disorder.
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Schizophrenia is characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech and behavior, and negative symptoms. None of these symptoms are seen in this patient.
❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Schizoid personality disorder describes people who are aloof and avoid social interaction. This patient is exceptionally attention-seeking, and her provocative behavior instead suggests a diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder.
❌ Narcissistic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although individuals with narcissistic personality disorder exhibit attention-seeking behavior, they do not display dramatic emotions. Other characteristic features of narcissistic personality disorder, such as lack of empathy and interpersonal exploitation, are not seen in this patient.
✅ Histrionic personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old person comes to the office after being referred by their employer for evaluation. The patient is a blog writer and was assigned a new project three months ago. The patient became annoyed when their employer asked to transfer the assignment to another employer because they did not complete it on time despite being granted several extensions. They usually refuse to let others take on their tasks because they think that only they can complete them satisfactorily. They say, “My colleagues never understand how important it is to do things the right way.” The patient states that they have trouble falling asleep at night because they think about assignments, and they sometimes go through their rough drafts multiple times to “make sure the blog looks flawless.” When asked why they revise their drafts multiple times, the patient laughs nervously and states, "I always repeat things." They live alone and do not regularly participate in social activities, stating, “It’s a waste of time.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control is consistent with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD), a cluster C personality disorder.  

Individuals with OCPD are obsessed with orderliness, perfectionism, and having complete control, as well as a tendency to rigidly follow rules, details, and schedules. Individuals with this disorder can often be inflexible and easily stressed as well as surprisingly inefficient because they spend so much extra time planning and worrying about tasks rather than simply completing them. They also tend to be very rigid when it comes to beliefs and moral issues, which leads them to be perceived as stubborn.  

The name “obsessive compulsive personality disorder” seems similar to “obsessive compulsive disorder,” or OCD, which is a different disorder that does have some overlap in symptoms. The two conditions are compared in the chart below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder can manifest with recurrent worrying and insomnia. However, it usually involves severe anxiety caused by various aspects of daily life and significant social or occupational impairment; this patient is primarily worried about their work assignments, rather than multiple facets of life.
✅ Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obsessive-compulsive disorder:
Incorrect: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) manifests with recurrent worries that cause distress and insomnia. However, patients with OCD typically have very intrusive and time-consuming thoughts, images, or urges and demonstrate repetitive behaviors that are performed in response to these intrusions. Additionally, OCD is characteristically ego-dystonic, meaning patients typically recognize their symptoms as intrusive and distressing. There is no indication that this patient views their behavior as inappropriate.
❌ Narcissistic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although individuals with narcissistic personality disorder are often preoccupied with perfectionism and believe that others cannot do things as well as they can, the motivation results from the desire for praise and admiration rather than a need for orderliness and a sense of control, as seen in this patient.
❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by limited emotional expression and voluntary social withdrawal. There is no evidence of limited emotional range in this patient, and their rationale for  not participating in social activities is because of their excessive devotion to work and insistence on doing things their way.
